intro: Seriphidium semiaridum, commonly known as the desert hawkweed, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and finely divided leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions through its deep root system and reduced leaf surface area. Its yellow flowers bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Seriphidium semiaridum plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native habitat and is often found in disturbed or open areas.
